div.head: Egyptian Antiquities.
div.p:
—The reader will find on
the outside a pleasant account of the doings of the
Prussian Scientific Expedition in Atrica. Mr. Lep-
sius, the leader of it, reported to Berlin early in the
summer, and Humboldt, in a letter to Mons. Jornald,
gives the following statement of the results of the
expedition:

“Thirteen hundred magnificent drawings, from
thousands of sketches taken on the spot, and all the
manuscripts, have already arrived here. Two ves-
sels, laden with the monuments themselves, were to
sail (from Egypt) in April. M. Lepsius brings with
him fragments of monuments of all dynasties, from
the fourth of Manetho down to the Ptolemies, and of
the Roman Emperors below Caracalla down to De-
cius. These original monuments, with the names of
the fourth, fifth and sixth dynasties, from two thou-
sand to three thousand years before our era, will be
of great importance in our new Egyptian Museum,
for everything before the invasion of the Hykshos is
very rare, even at Turin, at Paris, and at London. I
say nothing to you of the two bilingual decrees, co-
pied at Philæ, because I believe M. Ampere has sent
copies to you.

“The collection of images and inscriptions, found
in the country of the ancient copper mines of the
peninsula of Sinai, bearing the name of Cheops, is
of the greatest importance. Plaster casts from Wadi
—Megara—the illustrations and complete plans of
the Labyrinth—a colossal ram from Mount Bargal,
with the image and inscription of Amenophis—Mem-
non—the large stones of the Nilemetre of Senneh,
with the emblem of Amenemha-Moris, (proving that
4,000 years ago the mean height of the river in those
countries was 22 feet higher than it is now;) four
sepulchral chambers from the plateau of Gizeh, be-
longing as far back as the fourth dynasty; a colos-
sal bust of Horus, of the eighteenth dynasty; pro-
files of Amenophis and of Ahmes Nefanari; hun-
dreds of bricks with dates; and five large historical
papyri, like those of the British Museum, are trea-
sures which ought to bring you among us.

“M. Lepsius, before beginning his preparatory
Egyptian studies at Turin, at Pisa, at Rome, at Pa-
ris, and at London, had occupied himself wholly
with the study of Sanscrit, Greek, the Eugubian ta-
bles, and the philosophy of languages. Such philo-
sophical tastes have induced him in this journey to
collect complete materials—1st, on the Congara lan-
guage of the blacks of the interior; 2d, the Nuba
language of two dialects. Of this language, which
has never before been w ittenwritten, he has brought home
twenty or more songs and translations from the fa-
bles of Lokman, (known to English readers as Pil-
pay’s fables,) and some translations from a Thousand
and one Nights, which a Nubian had translated from
Arabic into the Nuba language; and 3d, the Bega
language, spoken between the Nubian Nile and the
Red Sea by the Bischari tribes. This is a branch of
the great family of Caucaso-Asiatic languages, al-
lied to the present form of the Ethiopian idiom of
Meroe.

“M. Lepsius has also, besides the Greek and Sinaitic
inscriptions, some ancient Ethiopian inscriptions,
found even in the pyramids of Meroe. These are an
unknown alphabet, sometimes a little analogous to
Greek characters. The knowledge of the Bega lan-
guage will facilitate the interpretation of them. The
study of this department of languages, so important
for the history of our race, is allied to the curious re-
searches of M. Roses, now a dragoman at Constan-
tinople, whom the King of Prussia sent to reside for
two years in the valleys of Caucasus, that he might
seek there in the language of the Ossetes, the origin
of the Indo-germanic branch, and in the Laze or
Mingrelien, the origin of the Iberian or Grusian
branch, to which belonged the language of ancient
Colchis. M. Roses is a brother of the great Indianist
who lately died at London. He will make his bro-
ther’s place perfectly good by the extent of his philo-
logical acquisitions and the vivacity of his genius.”—
[National Intelligencer.
